image.altText: Aurizon coal train generic shot

props.synopsis: Whyalla steelworks owner Sanjeev Gupta is facing another major challenge, with rail company Aurizon suspending some of its services for GFG Alliance over unpaid debts.

title.children: Rail operator Aurizon suspends services for GFG Alliance over unpaid debts

image.altText: a man in a business suit walks outside a court building

props.synopsis: A South Australian family says they forgive an Italian tourist whose "terrible error" caused a crash which killed three of their relatives in the state's Mid North last year, and say they do not believe he should be jailed.

title.children: Family forgives Italian tourist for 'serious lapse' which caused triple-fatal crash

image.altText: Adelaide United assistant coach Travis Dodd and defender Bailey O'Neil

props.synopsis: The current A-League Men's competition has less than a handful of Indigenous players, but emerging talent Bailey O'Neil and mentor Travis Dodd want to "get that ball rolling" when it comes to improving pathways.

title.children: Bailey O'Neil is one of just three Indigenous players in the A-League Men — he hopes to inspire more

image.altText: A woman with short blonde hair wearing a pink and tan dress leans on a marble kitchen bench smiling and looking off camera.

props.synopsis: The cook was named Best Host of a TV Format Award at the C21 International Format Awards for the ABC show Maggie Beer's Big Mission, a project aiming to overhaul the aged care industry's dismal catering.

title.children: Maggie Beer wins international TV award, beating industry legends Jimmy Kimmel and Stephen Fry

image.altText: Workers using a reach truck to repair power lines at a tall electricity tower

props.synopsis: The tribunal overseeing energy prices in New South Wales is investigating whether power infrastructure company Transgrid failed to provide a reliable supply to residents in the far west after a second outage within a week.

title.children: Investigation launched, power back on after backup generator failed in Broken Hill

image.altText: Hainsworth interview

props.synopsis: Steven Hainsworth was arrested in 2019, 21 years after allegedly murdering the first of three victims. He has spent the past two months listening intently to evidence from the Supreme Court dock.

title.children: From arrest to trial, this is how the case of an accused serial killer unfolded

image.altText: Woman speaking into microphone outside parliament house.

props.synopsis: University of Adelaide law academic Joanna Howe has posted to social media labelling female politicians 'baby killers' following a failure to change South Australian abortion laws.

title.children: Anti-abortion activist brands female politicians 'baby killers' in social media post

image.altText: A 15-year-old girl sitting on a couch and looking at her phone.

props.synopsis: The federal government's proposed social media ban is likely to be detrimental to some teens, particularly for young people in isolated and marginalised communities, experts and teenagers say.

title.children: Why the proposed social media ban could do more harm than good

image.altText: A brown snake rearing up with it's mouth open, on red grassy soil.

props.synopsis: A toxicologist warns it's never safe to assume a snake bite is free of venom, after a South Australian man experiences a delayed reaction to poison from a suspected brown snake bite.

title.children: Snake bite victim's 'unusual' 15-hour wait before venom kicks in

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and glasses looks ahead

props.synopsis: The head of GFG Alliance Sanjeev Gupta says there will be no more job losses at the Whyalla steelworks, while not being able to give a firm timeline on when he expects the blast furnace to come online again.

title.children: Whyalla steelworks owner promises no more job cuts with blast furnace to be fixed in 'days or weeks'

image.altText: A yellow metal bar gate with the nuclear symbol on it

props.synopsis: Taiwan is months away from phasing out its last nuclear plant, and while some are happy, others question how the tech powerhouse will power itself.

title.children: Taiwan's only months away from shutting off all nuclear power, but some question whether the tech powerhouse is ready

image.altText: smart phone with meta logo on it in front of blue background with facebook logo

props.synopsis: A tech tax might be the federal government’s path out of a six-month stalemate with Meta over the company’s refusal to pay for Australian news, writes Ange Lavoipierre.

title.children: Could Meta's stalemate with Australia spark a tech tax?

image.altText: A line of police separates a counter-rally from an anti-trans rally outside Victoria's Parliament House.

props.synopsis: A highly trained member of Victoria Police's riot squad allegedly punched a protester in the throat and assaulted two others during a controversial rally in Melbourne last year, according to three fresh lawsuits against the force.

title.children: Protesters sue police over alleged assaults during Melbourne trans-rights rally

image.altText: Tim Heath sitting in an office.

props.synopsis: Australian billionaire Tim Heath survived a kidnapping attempt by fighting off his alleged abductors who had pretended to be tradies painting the hallway of his apartment building.

title.children: Australian billionaire Tim Heath fights off alleged abductors dressed as painters in his apartment building

image.altText: Side by side photos of Anthony Albanese, looking up in a green tie, and Donald Trump, looking serious in a red tie

props.synopsis: If Donald Trump wins the US presidency on November 5, his victory will have profound implications for other countries on many fronts. Not least of them will be climate change policy.

title.children: When it comes to climate, Labor is keeping an eye on Washington before it looks to Paris

image.altText: A screengrab of a webpage showing flights over the Middle East.

props.synopsis: As Israel and Iran trade blows in the Middle East, commercial aircraft traversing the region are doing so through fewer corridors to avoid getting caught in the crossfire.

title.children: How war in the Middle East is impacting air travel over the region

image.altText: A woman in full personal protective equipment holding flasks containing pink fluid in a laboratory.

props.synopsis: The Alfred Hospital hosts one of a handful of labs around Australia working on engineered skin, a promising therapy that uses lab-grown cells suspended in sheets that can be grafted onto deep burns.

title.children: Clinical trial to test engineered skin on severe burns starts in Melbourne hospital

image.altText: A half broken bridge on a river after it collapsed during floods

props.synopsis: As one of the deadliest typhoons in decades ripped through Vietnam, a harrowing video of a bridge collapsing emerged on social media. And while the storm dealt the final blow to the bridge, it may not be the only thing responsible for the tragedy.

title.children: The sand mines, the typhoon and the deadly bridge collapse

image.altText: Three men in military gear walk on a footpath as an armoured vehicle drives past on the road.

props.synopsis: Türkiye's relationship with Kurdish nationalists is the political problem that won't go away.

title.children: The PKK's Ankara attack escalated conflict in Türkiye. Leaders are debating how to end it

image.altText: Jad is at the front of a hidden cave, with a friend. He's not wearing a shirt, and swimming shorts.

props.synopsis: Lebanese people are coming together to help house and feed the 1.2 million displaced people in Lebanon, as the country marks 30 days of war. From Australia to the heart of Beirut, they're uniting together to help the country and its people.

title.children: Jad used to chase waterfalls in Lebanon. Now he's collecting donations to help 1.2 million displaced people

image.altText: Large submarine

props.synopsis: The latest in autonomous marine technology has been showcased during secretive AUKUS exercises on the NSW south coast with defence officials signalling Japan could soon be involved in the maritime activity.

title.children: Japanese officials observe secretive Jervis Bay exercises ahead of likely AUKUS invitation

image.altText: A man with his back turned in the foreground, a building with a hole blown out in the middle, and a crowd of people behind.

props.synopsis: An Israeli strike on a school where displaced people were sheltering in the central Gaza Strip has killed at least 16 people and wounded 32 more, Palestinian health officials say.

title.children: At least 17 Palestinians killed in Israeli strike on Gaza school, health officials say

image.altText: Close up of Richard White smiling on stage.

props.synopsis: Tesla boosts Wall Street, leaving local futures pointing higher. WiseTech's Richard White steps down but not out of the company. Qantas will hold its annual meeting as engineers strike. Follow the day's events on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX poised to rise, WiseTech shares in focus as boss steps aside, Qantas AGM ahead

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: What to expect at the Qantas AGM
Tesla surges — adding more value in a day than GM and Ford combined

image.altText: Three men in high vis and hard hats talk to the media

props.synopsis: Tasmania's business and tourism groups have grown increasingly fed up with the state government over its handling of the new Spirit of Tasmania vessels. That anger overflowed on Thursday.

title.children: 'A calamity for Tasmania': Premier wanted calm seas over Spirits fiasco, but now he faces a storm

image.altText: Farmer standing in a field with a phone.

props.synopsis: There are concerns thousands of phones, medical devices, mobile phone boosters in cars, location devices in trucks and farm equipment may stop working.

title.children: The 3G network is about to shut down for good, so what will stop working from Monday?

image.altText: Girl wearing violet dress and white paint holding stick in a forest.

props.synopsis: A recent report has called for a new First Nations tourism body. Those on the ground know the challenges faced by budding business owners.

title.children: 'Storytelling was our TV': First Nations tourism operators love sharing their culture, but getting started can be a challenge

image.altText: A husband looks down at his wife who stares at the camera.

props.synopsis: Thai migrant Paphatsiri "Net" Woolcock has lived in a remote WA mining town for almost a decade and has two children, but has failed the test five times.

title.children: Australia's updated citizenship test is proving too hard for many — Net has failed it five times

image.altText: First Nations DV announcement

props.synopsis: This community organisation is helping women spot the signs their relationship might be in danger. Here's how you can too.

title.children: How to spot the early warning signs in your relationship

image.altText: Richard White seated at a wooden boardroom table with a tablet in front of him.

props.synopsis: Richard White has announced he will step down as the CEO of WiseTech Global, effective immediately, after a series of allegations against him wiped billions off the company's share price.

title.children: 'Now is the right time': Richard White steps down as WiseTech Global CEO

image.altText: A rusted pipe pushes out hot water into a small pond

props.synopsis: In a region that grows a quarter of the nation's fruit and vegetables, farmers are worried a new national water policy will grind future investment to a halt and put water security at risk.

title.children: Farmers say agricultural water security under a cloud in new national water plan

image.altText: An illustration of a shadowy figure in the distance with the Israeli flag in the front

props.synopsis: Models, businessmen and even former politicians have been picked up by Israeli intelligence agencies after allegedly working for Iran.

title.children: Israelis are being recruited by Iran for espionage operations. Now, they're being caught

image.altText: Lidia Thorpe at a press conference.

props.synopsis: King Charles's royal tour had time for greetings, meetings and photo opportunities, but not for the difficult work of reparations to First Nations Australians. In the absence of the time and space to discuss, inevitably there will be protest and anger.

title.children: Lidia Thorpe’s confrontation of the King comes as calls for reparations grow

image.altText: A man with a mic

props.synopsis: Brisbane's lord mayor refuses to return power to two homeless camps and vows to crack down even harder on "anti-social behaviour" at the tent cities.

title.children: Mayor refuses to return power to homeless camps after cutting electricity and barbecues

image.altText: an 18-year-old woman and man in his 50s inside a car looking at the camera smiling

props.synopsis: Cars are safer than ever, but the country's road toll is still increasing. Race car driver-turned-instructor Paul Morris says teaching road safety skills in schools could be the answer.

title.children: Australia's road toll is getting worse. Is the answer learning to drive at school?

image.altText: An artist's impression of a black hole drawing material off a nearby star. A second star is in the background.

props.synopsis: A system called V404 Cygni was thought to be a black hole and a companion star, but another star billions of kilometres away was also found gravitationally connected to the duo.

title.children: First 'black hole triple system' discovered by astronomers
